access-date =2015-08-31}} ==History== The Wimbledon Championships are played in the first two weeks of July (as of July 2017; prior to this, they were played in the last week of June and first week of July) and have chronologically been the third of the four [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] tournaments of the tennis [[Season (sports)|season]] since 1987. The event was not held from 1915 to 1918 because of World War I and again from 1940 to 1945 because of World War II.{{cite web|title=Gentlemen's Singles|url=http://www.wimbledon.com/en_GB/draws_archive/champions/gentlemenssingles.html|website=wimbledon.com|publisher=[[AELTC]]|access-date=2 March 2019}} It was also cancelled in 2020 due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].{{cite news|title=Wimbledon cancelled due to coronavirus – where does that leave tennis in 2020?|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/52104196|first=Russell|last=Fuller|date=1 April 2020|access-date=1 April 2020|publisher=BBC Sport}} [[File:Lawn tennis drawing, newspaper, around 1879.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Wimbledon Lawn tennis final, 15 July 1879.]] The Gentlemen's Singles' rules have undergone several changes since the first edition. From [[1878 Wimbledon Championship|1878]] until [[1921 Wimbledon Championships|1921]], the event started with a [[Single-elimination tournament|knockout]] phase, the All Comers' Singles, whose winner then faced the defending champion in a [[Glossary of tennis terms#Challenge Round|challenge round]]. The All Comers' winner was automatically awarded the title six times ([[1879 Wimbledon Championships|1879]], [[1887 Wimbledon Championships|1887]], [[1891 Wimbledon Championships|1891]], [[1895 Wimbledon Championships|1895]], [[1907 Wimbledon Championships|1907]], [[1908 Wimbledon Championships|1908]]) in the absence of the previous year's champion. The challenge round system was abolished with the [[1922 Wimbledon Championships|1922]] edition.{{Cite book | title =100 Wimbledon Championships: A Celebration |isbn=978-0-00-218220-1 |publisher=Collins Willow|first=John|last=Barrett|author-link =John Barrett (tennis)|year=1986}} Since the first championships, all matches have been played at the [[Tennis score#Scoring a set|best-of-five sets]]. Between 1877 and [[1883 Wimbledon Championship|1883]], the winner of the next game at five games all took the set in every match except the All Comers' final, and the challenge round, which were won with six games and a two games advantage. All sets were decided in this [[advantage format]] from [[1884 Wimbledon Championships|1884]] to [[1970 Wimbledon Championships|1970]]. The best-of-12-points [[Glossary_of_tennis_terms#L|lingering death tie-break]] was introduced in [[1971 Wimbledon Championships|1971]] for the first four sets, played at eight games all until [[1978 Wimbledon Championships|1978]] and at six games all since [[1979 Wimbledon Championships|1979]].{{cite web|first=John|last= Roberts |work=[[The Independent]]|title=Tennis: Fast, fan friendly – but full of faults | url =https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/tennis-fast-fan-friendly--but-full-of-faults-1169793.html| date=1998-08-05| access-date =2009-06-24}}{{cite web|work=[[The Age]]|title=Breaking with tradition| url =http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/01/24/1074732652848.html?from=storyrhs| date=2004-01-25|access-date =2009-07-27}} Since 1949, the Gentlemen's Singles champion has received a miniature replica of the event's trophy, a [[silver-gilt]] cup created in 1887 with the engraved inscription: "The All England Lawn Tennis Club Single Handed Champion of the World".{{cite web|title=About Wimbledon – Trophies|url=http://www.wimbledon.com/en_GB/atoz/trophies.html|website=wimbledon.com|publisher=[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Championships]]|access-date=8 October 2017}} New singles champions are traditionally elected honorary members of the AELTC by the club's committee.{{efn|name=McEnroeMembership|[[John McEnroe]] is the only player to have been denied membership in [[1981 Wimbledon Championships|1981]], because of his on-court behaviour during the championships.{{cite web|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|agency=[[United Press International]]|title=Jolly snub for McEnroe; he's refused All-England| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19810710&id=HvcNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F3sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4541,1270028| date=1981-07-10|access-date =2009-07-27}}{{cite magazine|first=Avi|last=Zenilman|magazine=[[The New Yorker]]|title=Back Issues: McEnroe vs. Thatcher| url =http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2009/06/back-issues-john-mcenroe-vs-margaret-thatcher.html| date=2009-06-24|access-date =2009-07-27}}}}{{cite web|title=About Wimbledon – About the AELTC|url=http://www.wimbledon.com/en_GB/atoz/about_aeltc.html|website=wimbledon.com|publisher=[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Championships]]|access-date=8 October 2017}} In 2017, the Gentlemen's Singles winner received [[prize money]] of [[Pound sterling|£]]2,220,000.{{cite web|title=About Wimbledon – Prize Money and Finance|url=http://www.wimbledon.com/en_GB/aboutwimbledon/prize_money_and_finance.html|website=wimbledon.com|publisher=[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Championships]]|access-date=8 October 2017}} In the Amateur Era, [[William Renshaw]] (1881–1886, 1889) holds the record for the most titles in the Gentlemen's Singles, winning Wimbledon seven times. Renshaw's wins, however, came within the challenge round format, and he won the event only twice after going through a complete draw. Renshaw also holds the record for most consecutive titles with six (from 1881 to 1886). The record for most consecutive and most wins post challenge round during the Amateur Era is [[Fred Perry]] with three (1934–1936). In the Open Era, since the inclusion of professional tennis players in 1968, [[Roger Federer]] (2003–2007, 2009, 2012, 2017) holds the record for the most Gentlemen's Singles titles with eight. [[Björn Borg]] (1976–1980) and [[Roger Federer]] (2003–2007) share the record for most consecutive victories with five. Federer reached 7 consecutive Wimbledon Finals (2003 – 09), an all-time record, surpassing the old record of 6 consecutive finals by Borg (1976–81) and in the process the Swede won 41 consecutive matches at Wimbledon. This event was won without losing a single set in the entire tournament during the Open Era twice, in 1976 by Björn Borg and in 2017 by Roger Federer. [[Roger Federer]] is the only player in history, in both the Amateur and Open Eras, to reach the Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles Final twelve times. For 9 consecutive years from 1992 to 2000, an American player reached Wimbledon final winning 8 titles out of 9, only exception being 1996 Runner Up [[MaliVai Washington]], a new open era record. ==Champions== ===Amateur era=== [[File:William Renshaw 1880.jpg|thumb|right|200px|William Renshaw was the first man to win seven championships.]] [[File:Messrs.
